q1.value: The Impact of the Educational Support Climate on Adolescent Character, Emotional Development, and Academic Performance

q3.value: There has been considerable research connecting social support to positive outcomes in adolescents (Lerner & Calina, 2014; Bruner, Eys, Wilson, & Côté, 2014; for reviews, see Bianco & Eklund, 2001; Holt & Hoar, 2006; Rees, 2007). However, very few studies have examined the impact of multiple forms of support found in the educational context on the character, emotional development, and performance of adolescence. Increasingly, educators have attempted to determine the role character development plays in the performance outcomes of adolescents, given that both production and character have been linked to long-term positive results (Lerner & Castellino, 2002). The purpose of this study is to examine the impact of the climate of support provided by (parents, teachers, peers) found in educational settings on the character, emotional development, and academic performance of adolescents. Negative outcomes such as stress, depression, dropout rates, and risky behaviors have been associated with disengagement and dissatisfaction from school (Gutiérrez, Tomás, Romero, & Barrica, 2017). While social support from family, teachers, and peers has been associated with greater school engagement and more positive outcomes in adolescents such as better academic performance, life satisfaction and subjective well-being (Lewis, Huebner, Malone, & Valois, 2011; Gilman & Heubner, 2006; Suldo, Shaffer, & Riley, 2008). Results from these studies indicate that further exploration is necessary to determine what aspects of the educational support environment impacts specific elements of character and emotional development and whether there is a difference in performance and character outcomes based on the amount/type of social support received by an adolescent. Teachers and administrators are committed to the success of their students but often lack detailed information into how they can best serve the whole student. Previous studies suggest that by targeting student engagement and well-being, then academic success will follow (Lewis, Huebner, Malone, & Valois, 2011; Lyons & Huebner, 2015; Suldo et al., 2011). Although this is likely an accurate conclusion, it is incomplete in directing school officials on how to improve student engagement and well-being. The results require clarification as to what types of external support are needed to facilitate various form

q4.value:
Students with higher levels of social support will have better well-being than those without social support. Higher levels of social support will be positively related to better academic outcomes.

Athletes will have higher levels of social support compared to non-athletic students. 

Emotion regulation abilities in students will be similar to the emotion regulation abilities of their parents. 

Emotion regulation will mediate the relationship between forms of social support and academic performance and well-being. 

Supportive school climate will be positively related to well-being variables (satisfaction with life, emotion regulation, purpose) and academic performance. A supportive school climate will be negatively related to the pressure to perform.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional survey study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network(CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers. For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer tohttps://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: We expect a sample of more than 1000 participants.

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above.

question.value:
1. Satisfaction with life is measured with the Satisfaction with Life Scale. Diener, Emmons, Larsen, and Griffin (1985) developed the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) to measure global satisfaction with life. 

2. Parental support, both mother and father, will be assessed using a 4-item parental support scale. It is used to assess perceived behaviors from mothers and fathers that communicate to the participant feelings of warmth, affection, and a sense of being valued (Bush, Peterson, Cobas, & Supple, 2002; Henry & Peterson, 1995; Peterson, Rollins, & Thomas, 1985). 

3. Non-parental support (coaches support) was measured with the 16-item Perceived Available Support in Sport Questionnaire (PASS-Q; Freeman, Coffee, & Rees, 2011). 

4. ERQ- Gross and John’s (2003) Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ) will be used to measure individual variation in emotion regulation. 

5. Student Assess Parental ERQ (Mother and Father)
Students will be asked to assess their parents' emotion regulation ability via Gross and John’s (2003) Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ). 

6. Fear of failure appraisal
A Performance Failure Appraisal Inventory (PFAI; Conroy, Willow, Metzler, 2010) will be used to assess the students' fear of failure. 

7. School Climate 
We will assess the quality of participants’ school environments using the following scale:  Student Perceptions of School Cohesion (Arrivallaga et al., 2009). This 10-item scale requires students to rate with a 5-point response scale their perceptions of the school social environment (e.g., “I feel a part of this school”)

8. Pressure to Perform
Participants will rate the degree to which they currently feel pressure to compete in sports and school. Ratings were made on separate 5-point scales (1 = no pressure; 5 = a lot of pressure). 

9. CESD
A screen for depression and other psychological disorders in adolescents (CESD; Garrison, Addy, Jackson, McKeown, Waller, 1991) was used to test for depressive symptoms. 

10. Purpose 
We will examine students' perspectives of purpose using the Claremont Purpose Scale (Bronk, Rcihes, Mangan, 2018). 

11. Performance-based identity scale 

In addition, Character Lab Research Network via the school will collect demographic data including age, gender, ethnicity, grade level, and SES indicators.

In general, models will be run without covariates. We may include demographic variables (e.g., gender, race/ethnicity) as covariates in follow-up models 

ANOVAs will be run to assess the differences between student groups. Students will be divided in half based on reported levels of support. The two groups will be compared based on outcome variables of satisfaction of life, performance, emotion regulation, purpose, fear of failure, performance-based identity. 

Students who indicate they are athletes will be compared to non-athletes along the study's variables. 

Path Analysis and Structural equation modeling. Support variables (school, mother, father, coaches) will be included in both path and SEM models as independent variables. All other variables will be assessed as dependent variables. 

Mediation will be assessed using indirect effect models with 5,000 bootstrapped samples and bias-corrected 95% confidence intervals. Emotion regulation, fear of failure, and performance-based identity will be included as mediations within the model between sources of support and all other study variables.

q20.value: We do not anticipate needing transformation of data, but if necessary, we will transform skewed data using conventional techniques (e.g., log transformation). We plan on using untransformed variables, with the following exception: Outliers (+/- 3.29 SD from the mean) will be Winsorized to the nearest value that is not an outlier.

q21.value: We will use a two-tailed p-value of .05 as the threshold for significance. Effect sizes and confidence intervals will be reported. Because we have only one primary outcome variable (self-reported meaning), we do not plan on using adjustments for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
We will exclude respondents who meet at least one of the following criteria:
- not being a student (e.g., a teacher who pilots the study)
- not being a student in the school assigned to us by Character Lab Research Network
- participating in multiple RCTs or pilots in the same session
- being enrolled in grade other than 9th, 10th, 11th, or 12th
- not matching school-provided data.

q23.value: We will use intent-to-treat (ITT) analyses and also examine and report evidence for selective attrition.

In addition, Character Lab Research Network via the school will collect demographic data including age, gender, ethnicity, grade level, and SES indicators.
registration_responses.q19.question:
In general, models will be run without covariates. We may include demographic variables (e.g., gender, race/ethnicity) as covariates in follow-up models 

ANOVAs will be run to assess the differences between student groups. Students will be divided in half based on reported levels of support. The two groups will be compared based on outcome variables of satisfaction of life, performance, emotion regulation, purpose, fear of failure, performance-based identity. 

Students who indicate they are athletes will be compared to non-athletes along the study's variables. 

Path Analysis and Structural equation modeling. Support variables (school, mother, father, coaches) will be included in both path and SEM models as independent variables. All other variables will be assessed as dependent variables. 

Mediation will be assessed using indirect effect models with 5,000 bootstrapped samples and bias-corrected 95% confidence intervals. Emotion regulation, fear of failure, and performance-based identity will be included as mediations within the model between sources of support and all other study variables.

attributes.title: Comparing Methods for Brainstorming and Prioritization in a Participatory Environmental Monitoring Workshop

q1.value: Comparing Methods for Brainstorming and Prioritization in a Participatory Environmental Monitoring Workshop

q5.value: The workshop has been supported by the United Nations Development Program.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We all participate in workshops in order to generate new ideas, organize workplans, and prioritize activities. Yet how might the design of the workshop influence who participates and how satisfied we are with the outcomes of the workshop? We will run a field experiment that compares a structured approach to brainstorming and prioritization with an unstructured approach. The workshop will take place the first week of October in Panama City in the context of a workshop on participatory environmental monitoring.

q16.value: We hypothesize that the structured workshop will produce better outcomes across most self-reported survey responses. The outcomes of the workshop will be measured in pre and post survey responses from participants.

q17.value: We will test these using an ordered logistic regression that compares treatment and control groups on a series of outcome variables, controlling for gender and institutional affiliation.

q27.value: The research will be implemented by a team of third party facilitators hired by UNDP. Bruno Patrini and Mitzy Canessa

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan for an Experiment on Electoral Preferences: Evidence from Uruguay

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan for an Experiment on Electoral Preferences: Evidence from Uruguay

q5.value: Juan A. Bogliaccini acknowledges this study is partially funded by the Clemente Estable Fund (FCE_1_2017_1_135444), Agencia Nacional de Investigación e Innovación (ANII).

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In electoral systems where rules do not allow to split the ticket for the simultaneous parliamentary and presidential election, focusing either on candidates or parties while asking for vote intention may produce significant differences in vote report. Specifically, focusing on candidates or parties may produce differences in the level of decidedness of respondent´s vote intention, in the vote share of candidates running on parties with strong party identification and in the vote share of candidates running on parties with weak or none party identification. Uruguay, with the highest democratic record in the region alongside Costa Rica and Chile, has also a highly institutionalized party system (Mainwaring and Scully 1995, Coppedge 1998, Siavelis 2000). Alongside Chile, Uruguay is the other country in Latin America where the partisan divide as a component of left-right self-placement is higher, with values that are almost twice the regional average (Alcántara and Luna 2004; Luna and Zechmeister 2005; Kitschelt et al. 2010). The Uruguayan party system is, again with Chile in the Latin American context, the one with the highest scores of programmatic structuration; classified as a case of intermediate programmatic structuration (Kitschelt et al. 2010). We take advantage of the upcoming electoral cycle in Uruguay, where the electoral system salsifies the proposed condition of not allowing a split ticket for the simultaneous parliamentary and presidential elections, to test our postulate by means of a survey experiment.

q16.value: H1. In learning about vote preferences, there are differences in declared vote intention whether the question focuses on preferences about candidates or parties. H2. Given Uruguay’s strong and stable party identification levels, focusing on preferences only about candidates increases the levels of declared undecidedness. H3. For presidential candidates running on parties with strong party identification: a. Focusing on preferences only about parties generates higher levels of vote intention vis-à-vis focusing on preferences only about candidates. b. Focusing on preferences about parties but adding candidates’ cues generates lower shares of vote intention. H4. For presidential candidates running on parties with weak levels of party identification: a. Focusing on preferences only about candidates generates higher shares of vote intention vis-à-vis focusing on preferences only about parties. b. Focusing on preferences about candidates but adding parties’ cues generates lower shares of vote intention.

q17.value: We will sample between 1000 and 1600 adults in Uruguay. Each individual will be asked to respond to a question randomly assigned from the four different vignettes described in Section 2.2. Our power calculations indicated that we need at least 250 respondents in each treatment for hypothesis 1 to 4. We plan to have between the minimum of 250 to 400 respondents per vignette. We will recruit participants by advertising the survey via Facebook, a cost-effective tool particularly useful for recruiting populations in settings outside United States (Samuels and Zucco, 2013). From the advertisements, respondents will be directed to a Qualtrics survey. We will track implementation through Facebook and target different populations in the advertisements to achieve a more socio-demographically balanced sample. The full text of the Facebook advertisement in Spanish and in English as well as the different targeted audience is presented in the back of this research design. Besides the vignettes and its associated response, all respondents will answer several questions regardless of treatment -up to 24 questions in total- (depending on branching patterns). In particular, all respondents will be asked about candidate’s image, their party identification and a question related to whether parties or candidates rank more highly for Uruguayan voters.

registration_responses.q1: Pre-Analysis Plan for an Experiment on Electoral Preferences: Evidence from Uruguay
registration_responses.q5: Juan A. Bogliaccini acknowledges this study is partially funded by the Clemente Estable Fund (FCE_1_2017_1_135444), Agencia Nacional de Investigación e Innovación (ANII).

attributes.title: Social Norms of Voting – An Initial Test in Malawi

q1.value: Social Norms of Voting – An Initial Test in Malawi

q5.value: Thanks to Melina Platas for allowing me to add a question to her experimental study conducted in Malawi in 2018.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In the most recent (2014) general election in Malawi almost 70% of the eligible population voted. While numerous existing theories focus on explaining high voter turnout in developing democracies, social incentives and existing social norms have traditionally been understudied in these contexts. Scholars, however, have demonstrated that social norms of voting exist in other east African countries (Rosenzweig 2018). This registration details the use of a question included in another researcher’s lab-in-the-field experiment conducted in Malawi, which serves as an initial test of whether there may be a social norm of voting operating in rural Malawi. The study tests this idea by measuring individual’s perceptions of their fellow community members’ views toward abstainers. More details on the specific design of the experiment is available from Melina Platas’ EGAP-registered design (#20180814AA).

q16.value: H1: A majority of respondents believe that other people in their community view abstaining in elections as socially unacceptable. H2: The more reliant the community is on the government (measured by a lack of non-government service provision) the stronger this perception of social disapproval for abstaining will be. I will also analyze where there is village-level heterogeneity in individuals’ perceptions of the norm based on village size (population and density), ethnic and religious diversity, partisanship, and level of poverty. In the future I also hope to collect local-level data from the 2019 general election in order to see how closely village-level perceptions match actual behavior.

q17.value: My question of interest asked individuals to indicate whether they think other people from their village who were in their experimental session believe that “An adult does not vote on election day” is socially acceptable or socially unacceptable. The measure involved a 4-point scale with smiley/frown-face emoji to help communicate the concept to illiterate participants. To test H1 I will observe whether over 50% of respondents believe that others think abstaining in elections is socially unacceptable, by taking the average answer across all sessions and villages. I will also look at heterogeneity in beliefs by regressing belief on gender, age, education, religion, ethnicity and income. I will also include the number of other group participants the individual said they know well and the length of time the respondent lived in that village to understand how having more information might influence the results. To test H2 I will average across all three sessions in each village and then compare the mean responses across villages that have access to non-government schools and clinics, compared to those that only have government services. Note: This experiment primed religion. The three sessions in each village varied in the composition of subjects based on their religion. While I do not anticipate any differences in expected attitudes toward abstaining on the basis of religion, I will test for differences across these three groups in the same village. I anticipate that any observed differences will be due to the fact that homogeneous groups may have better information about what others in the group believe. Differences in the norm could also be explained by any differences in how Muslims and Christians perceive of the utility of voting in elections (in terms of the chances of accessing government resources). Specifically, since the current President of Malawi (and most presidents) is Christian, Muslim groups or majority Muslim villages may not have a norm of voting if they do not believe that voting in elections increases their chances of accessing government resources.

q19.value: 720 respondents across 20 villages. In each village there were 3 experimental sessions with 12 people per session.

attributes.title: Institutional Remedies for Affective Polarization: Evidence from Israel

q1.value: Institutional Remedies for Affective Polarization: Evidence from Israel

q5.value: We thank Noam Gidron, Micheal Masterson, Ellie Powell, Jonathan Renshon, and Lior Sheffer for helpful comments and suggestions.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We leverage the current ambiguity around coalition building in Israel’s 21st election to credibly shape respondents’ perceptions regarding the likelihood that a unity government will form in the near future. In doing so, we build on Tankard and Paluck (2017), and implement a survey experiment in which we expose treated respondents to a brief vignette suggesting that political experts expect that within the next week, it is most likely that a unity government will form. Controlled subjects are exposed to one of two vignettes informing subjects that (i) political experts expect that within the next week Israel will go for a third round of elections, or (ii) providing subjects with a neutral piece of information about the weather in Israel. We expect that our treatment, priming institutionalized partisan cooperation in the form of a grand unity coalition, will reduce affective polarization. Building on recent advances we theorize that this effect is driven by mechanisms of shared national identity, elite cues, and increased ideological ambiguity across parties (Levendusky, 2018a,b). We further consider whether institutionalized partisan cooperation affects attitudes towards minorities which are not incorporated in grand coalitions. Here, we expect that grand coalitions will impair Intergroup relations with minority social groups (in the Israeli case Ultra-Orthodox Jews and Palestinian citizens of Israel).

q16.value: H1: Information about unity governments will reduce affective polarization. H2: Information about unity governments will increase animosity towards minorities.

q17.value: Survey Experiment (See PAP for further detail)

q27.value: Survey experiment will be implemented by IPanel

registration_responses.q1: Institutional Remedies for Affective Polarization: Evidence from Israel

Controlled subjects are exposed to one of two vignettes informing subjects that (i) political experts expect that within the next week Israel will go for a third round of elections, or (ii) providing subjects with a neutral piece of information about the weather in Israel. We expect that our treatment, priming institutionalized partisan cooperation in the form of a grand unity coalition, will reduce affective polarization. Building on recent advances we theorize that this effect is driven by mechanisms of shared national identity, elite cues, and increased ideological ambiguity across parties (Levendusky, 2018a,b). We further consider whether institutionalized partisan cooperation affects attitudes towards minorities which are not incorporated in grand coalitions. Here, we expect that grand coalitions will impair Intergroup relations with minority social groups (in the Israeli case Ultra-Orthodox Jews and Palestinian citizens of Israel).

attributes.title: Preanalysis Plan for Campaign Finance Disclosure and the Policy-Valence Tradeoff

q1.value: Preanalysis Plan for Campaign Finance Disclosure and the Policy-Valence Tradeoff

q5.value: I appreciate CA FWD’s support of this research.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: A little-examined kind of transparency is that of candidates making the details of their campaign financing transparent. They can comply with legal transparency requirements, but they can also over-comply or under-comply. If a candidate misses a disclosure deadline, she may be disorganized, but if she hides a contribution, she may be disorganized or she may be ``crooked''. Disorganization is important, because elected officials perform clerk like tasks (Neustadt 1960). But potential corruption or illegality is probably more alarming to most voters. In related work, I show that voters are willing to reward over-compliance and punish under-compliance (Wood 2017). In this project, I ask how their willingness to reward and punish campaign finance transparency varies with other candidate characteristics, including policy preferences. The tradeoffs between candidates who are high on valence characteristics and those who are attractive along policy dimensions has not been explored very deeply in the literature (c.f. Franchino, 2015, Groseclose 2007) and has never been addressed with transparency (campaign finance or otherwise) as a part of the analysis. This study will help us understand how voters view transparency when it is competing with other candidate features, including their policy preferences. This is an important time to learn about candidate transparency, because campaign finance transparency is at a tenuous moment. Long the most robust area of campaign finance law, its support is weakening at elite levels. If campaign finance transparency is a valence characteristic, then Republican elites who are pushing for less campaign finance transparency (or enabling the Treasury and IRS to de-regulate in this area) are not representing the desires of their constituents in this area. Moreover, candidates in Republican primaries may be able to highlight their support of campaign finance transparency in order to contrast themselves with other candidates. Building on my prior work showing that voters reward over-compliance and punish support from dark money groups, I now consider to what degree will voters trade off on their preferred policies in order to support candidates who are more transparent?

q16.value: See attached PAP, but generally: 1. (Primary) In general, among the campaign finance transparency attributes, I expect to observe electoral rewards for transparency and electoral punishments for lack of transparency. Moreover, I expect that the punishments will be larger than the rewards. 2. Voters will compromise more on their preferred levels of transparency than they will on their preferred policies. As the policy distance between the respondent and the candidate decreases, respondents' willingness to reward transparency or punish lack of transparency will decrease 3. Respondents' ideological extremity and policy distance between the respondent and the candidate should interact to affect reactions to transparency, so: a. Transparency will be more important to people who are deeply engaged or ideologically very committed. b. However, as policy preference distance between the respondent and the candidate increase, reaction of the more deeply engaged and ideologically extreme to transparency issues will be more muted than reaction to transparency by of the less deeply engaged and ideologically extreme. 4. (Exploratory): a. If transparency is a valence characteristic, I will observe no difference between respondents from different parties. b. If transparency is a partisan issue, respondents from different parties will react differently to transparency, and if Republicans are following their elites, they should have the smaller reaction. c. It is also possible that extreme partisans will treat transparency as a partisan issue, whereas more moderate people will treat it as a valence issue. 5. (Exploratory): a candidate's campaign finance transparency is more important to voters than the amount the candidate has raised but less important than the candidate's grasp of the issues and ability to be persuasive in public.

q17.value: Conjoint analysis as described in the attached PAP.

registration_responses.q1: Preanalysis Plan for Campaign Finance Disclosure and the Policy-Valence Tradeoff
registration_responses.q5: I appreciate CA FWD’s support of this research.

They can comply with legal transparency requirements, but they can also over-comply or under-comply. If a candidate misses a disclosure deadline, she may be disorganized, but if she hides a contribution, she may be disorganized or she may be ``crooked''. Disorganization is important, because elected officials perform clerk like tasks (Neustadt 1960). But potential corruption or illegality is probably more alarming to most voters. In related work, I show that voters are willing to reward over-compliance and punish under-compliance (Wood 2017). In this project, I ask how their willingness to reward and punish campaign finance transparency varies with other candidate characteristics, including policy preferences. The tradeoffs between candidates who are high on valence characteristics and those who are attractive along policy dimensions has not been explored very deeply in the literature (c.f. Franchino, 2015, Groseclose 2007) and has never been addressed with transparency (campaign finance or otherwise) as a part of the analysis. This study will help us understand how voters view transparency when it is competing with other candidate features, including their policy preferences. This is an important time to learn about candidate transparency, because campaign finance transparency is at a tenuous moment. Long the most robust area of campaign finance law, its support is weakening at elite levels. If campaign finance transparency is a valence characteristic, then Republican elites who are pushing for less campaign finance transparency (or enabling the Treasury and IRS to de-regulate in this area) are not representing the desires of their constituents in this area. (Primary) In general, among the campaign finance transparency attributes, I expect to observe electoral rewards for transparency and electoral punishments for lack of transparency. Moreover, I expect that the punishments will be larger than the rewards. 2. Voters will compromise more on their preferred levels of transparency than they will on their preferred policies. As the policy distance between the respondent and the candidate decreases, respondents' willingness to reward transparency or punish lack of transparency will decrease 3. Respondents' ideological extremity and policy distance between the respondent and the candidate should interact to affect reactions to transparency, so: a. Transparency will be more important to people who are deeply engaged or ideologically very committed. b. However, as policy preference distance between the respondent and the candidate increase, reaction of the more deeply engaged and ideologically extreme to transparency issues will be more muted than reaction to transparency by of the less deeply engaged and ideologically extreme. 4. (Exploratory): a. If transparency is a valence characteristic, I will observe no difference between respondents from different parties. b. If transparency is a partisan issue, respondents from different parties will react differently to transparency, and if Republicans are following their elites, they should have the smaller reaction. c. It is also possible that extreme partisans will treat transparency as a partisan issue, whereas more moderate people will treat it as a valence issue. 5. (Exploratory): a candidate's campaign finance transparency is more important to voters than the amount the candidate has raised but less important than the candidate's grasp of the issues and ability to be persuasive in public.

attributes.title: Assessing the Electoral Consequences of Interracial Marriage

q1.value: Assessing the Electoral Consequences of Interracial Marriage

q2.value: Paul Testa | David Skarbek | Brandon Davis

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Candidates’ spouses often figure prominently in campaigns. Conventional wisdom suggest voters may punish candidates, such as Kamala Harris, in interracial marriages race, presumably because voters draw inferences about the degree to which a candidate of their own race shares their identity and interests based on who that candidate chooses to marry. While considerable research demonstrates the relevance of other biographical and demographic characteristics of candidates for voter few studies to our knowledge have directly considered the electoral relevance of candidates' spouses. Using a set of factorial survey experiments, we assess the degree to which voters’ evaluations of hypothetical candidates change based on whether these candidates are in same-race or mixed-race marriages. As the U.S. becomes more racially diverse and interracial marriages become more common, the consequences of candidates with mixed race marriages figures to grow importance with broader implications for matters of descriptive representation and racial equality in the U.S.

q16.value: In this study, we use a set of factorial designs to examine how white and non-white voters evaluate candidates in same- and mixed-race marriages. We test the conventional wisdom that voters will punish candidates who marry outside their race, and explore the potential that these effects will vary by the gender of the candidate as well as the gender and attitudes of the voters.

q17.value: We test our expectations through a series of differences of means tests estimated via linear models.

registration_responses.q1: Assessing the Electoral Consequences of Interracial Marriage
registration_responses.q2: Paul Testa | David Skarbek | Brandon Davis

Using a set of factorial survey experiments, we assess the degree to which voters’ evaluations of hypothetical candidates change based on whether these candidates are in same-race or mixed-race marriages. attributes.title: The Effect of Relational Text Messaging on Turnout in the 2018 US Midterm Elections

q1.value: The Effect of Relational Text Messaging on Turnout in the 2018 US Midterm Elections

q2.value: Aaron Schein | Dhanya Sridhar | Keyon Vafa | Victor Veitch | Naseem Makiya | James Moffet | Jeff Quinn | David M. Blei | Donald Green

q9.value: We have obtained/analyzed a subset of the outcome data on turnout in the 2018 elections. We are awaiting data from six states: Utah, Arizona, West Virginia, Montana, Hawaii, North Dakota. Registration is thus prior to analysis of the full outcome data.

q15.value: We are interested in the causal effect of relational text messaging on voter turnout in U.S. elections. In other words, does receiving a reminder to vote via text message from a personal contact increase one’s likelihood of turning out to vote? Previous studies establish the causal effect of mail, phone banking, and door-to-door canvassing as “get out the vote” (GOTV) interventions. There are currently few studies on the effect of friend-to-friend (relational) organizing which is increasingly the focus of electoral campaigns.

q16.value: We seek to estimate the Complier Average Causal Effect (CACE) of receiving a message from a known contact on one’s likelihood to turn out in the 2018 U.S. Midterm Elections. Based on a subset of available outcome data (all states except Arizona, Hawaii, Montana, North Dakota, Utah, and West Virginia), we have estimated the CACE to be 4.39 ± 2.6 percentage points. Our current hypothesis is thus this estimate, pending data from the outstanding states.

q17.value: Outvote (https://www.outvote.io/) provides a mobile app that encourages users to message their friends to remind them to register and vote. In the run-up to the 2018 U.S. Midterm elections, Outvote conducted a randomized control trial by randomly excluding contacts (i.e., subjects) from the intended message queues of Outvote users. The population of excluded contacts thus created a control group of subjects that users intended to message but did not. We can then match subjects in the treatment and control groups to entries in the U.S. voter file using the name and phone numbers stored in users’ phones; this tells us whether a subject ultimately voted in the U.S. midterm elections (outcome). We have obtained and analyzed a subset of the outcome data on turnout in the 2018 elections. We are still missing turnout data from six states: Arizona, Hawaii, Montana, North Dakota, Utah, and West Virginia. Our hypothesis is based on calculations using the available turnout data. We will test our hypothesis by using the same methods on the remaining states. Specifically, we will estimate the Intent-to-Treat (ITT) effect using inverse propensity weighting based on the number of queues each subject appeared in. We will estimate the propensity weight by using the empirical probability of treatment for each stratum. The CACE will thus be the ITT divided by the causal effect of assignment on treatment.

q19.value: 143,167 subjects: 136,849 in the intended treatment group; 6,318 in the intended control group.

registration_responses.q1: The Effect of Relational Text Messaging on Turnout in the 2018 US Midterm Elections
registration_responses.q2: Aaron Schein | Dhanya Sridhar | Keyon Vafa | Victor Veitch | Naseem Makiya | James Moffet | Jeff Quinn | David M. Blei | Donald Green
registration_responses.q9: We have obtained/analyzed a subset of the outcome data on turnout in the 2018 elections. We are awaiting data from six states: Utah, Arizona, West Virginia, Montana, Hawaii, North Dakota. Registration is thus prior to analysis of the full outcome data.
registration_responses.q15: We are interested in the causal effect of relational text messaging on voter turnout in U.S. elections. In other words, does receiving a reminder to vote via text message from a personal contact increase one’s likelihood of turning out to vote? Previous studies establish the causal effect of mail, phone banking, and door-to-door canvassing as “get out the vote” (GOTV) interventions. There are currently few studies on the effect of friend-to-friend (relational) organizing which is increasingly the focus of electoral campaigns.
registration_responses.q16: We seek to estimate the Complier Average Causal Effect (CACE) of receiving a message from a known contact on one’s likelihood to turn out in the 2018 U.S. Midterm Elections. Based on a subset of available outcome data (all states except Arizona, Hawaii, Montana, North Dakota, Utah, and West Virginia), we have estimated the CACE to be 4.39 ± 2.6 percentage points. Our current hypothesis is thus this estimate, pending data from the outstanding states.
registration_responses.q17: Outvote (https://www.outvote.io/) provides a mobile app that encourages users to message their friends to remind them to register and vote. In the run-up to the 2018 U.S. Midterm elections, Outvote conducted a randomized control trial by randomly excluding contacts (i.e., subjects) from the intended message queues of Outvote users. The population of excluded contacts thus created a control group of subjects that users intended to message but did not. We can then match subjects in the treatment and control groups to entries in the U.S. voter file using the name and phone numbers stored in users’ phones; this tells us whether a subject ultimately voted in the U.S. midterm elections (outcome). We have obtained and analyzed a subset of the outcome data on turnout in the 2018 elections. We are still missing turnout data from six states: Arizona, Hawaii, Montana, North Dakota, Utah, and West Virginia. Our hypothesis is based on calculations using the available turnout data. We will test our hypothesis by using the same methods on the remaining states. Specifically, we will estimate the Intent-to-Treat (ITT) effect using inverse propensity weighting based on the number of queues each subject appeared in. We will estimate the propensity weight by using the empirical probability of treatment for each stratum. The CACE will thus be the ITT divided by the causal effect of assignment on treatment.
registration_responses.q19: 143,167 subjects: 136,849 in the intended treatment group; 6,318 in the intended control group.

attributes.title: Citizen-State Relations in Informal Settlements in Lagos, Nigeria

q1.value: Citizen-State Relations in Informal Settlements in Lagos, Nigeria

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Lagos, Nigeria, like other megacities across the globe serves as a symbol of promise and opportunity for those who call the city home. While the Nigerian government shares similar goals of growth for the city, in practice, development is uneven and leaves many of the city’s inhabitants behind. As the Lagos State government seeks to transform the country’s largest city into the next Dubai, it is faced with the question of how to develop its shopping malls and luxury apartment complexes while still upholding the social contract even with its poorest residents. Although there are some initiatives focused on inclusive development, the government has often adopted a strategy of simply trying to remove informal street hawkers and residents of informal settlements, through arrests, evictions, and demolitions. As a result, some residents of informal settlements fear being forcefully evicted from their homes by the government or overnight demolition of their entire community. From an outsider’s perspective, it would appear that the state has broken its social contract with these citizens. When services no longer function and the state is seen as the predator, rather than protector, how do citizens view the government and make decisions about engaging with it? The goal of this pilot study is to explore the relationship between residents of informal settlements in this megacity and the government. We study these questions in Lagos because it serves as the nexus of tensions between the state’s implementation of its goals and citizens’ interests. And because its promise of opportunity is also a draw for migrants, Lagos is characterized by religious and ethnic diversity.

q16.value: This study investigates how exposure to forced evictions correlates with mistrust of the state, investment in livelihoods, and political and community engagement. When residents are uncertain of what tomorrow might hold for them, how do they make economic investment decisions and choices about participating in political activities? How do they decide whether to engage and collaborate with their neighbors? Since state provision of social services is sparse in these settlements, community members may need to cooperate to self-provide. We examine intra-community dynamics and explore how individuals relate to and rely on other members of their community for both economic and social benefits. We also explore citizens’ relationships with local leaders, including traditional chiefs (baales), community development association (CDA) officials. These leaders likely play important roles as intermediaries with the state and community organizers. We are also interested in the role of traditional landowning elites, who are often politically powerful and may themselves either protect or predate on communities.

q17.value: Most hypotheses will be tested using linear regression. First, the bivariate relationship will be tested with a single regressor. Then the specified controls for will also be added. We will also look at heterogeneous effects. All regressions will include community and enumerator fixed effects. Hypotheses tested with survey experiments will be tested using a standard difference-in-means test. In addition, we will use linear regression and include our standard controls and measures to investigate heterogeneous treatment effects. We will also include community and enumerator fixed effects. See Pre-Analysis Plan (pages 3-9, “Empirical Strategy” sections) for more details.
